lesson.title: Data Producers
lesson.summary: This lesson is about systems or services that produce data.

atoms.title: Data Producers Heading
atoms.text: # Data Producers

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L3 01 Data Producer Heading
Lesson Overview
atoms.text:
## Lesson Overview
- Data Producers
- Event Data Continued
    - Event Data Modeling
- Data Producers
- Data Types
    - Structured, semi-structured and unstructured data

atoms.title: Lesson Exercises
atoms.text:
#### Important: Keep a Copy of your Exercise Responses in the Template Document
It is highly recommended that as you complete the open-ended exercises in this course, you should keep them in the provided template document to refer back to throughout the course. It will be advantageous as you complete the Final Exercise in the course: Knapsack Data Strategy MVP in the Data Strategy section of this course. You can still copy and paste your responses into the text boxes on each page in the course for each exercise if you wish.

atoms.title: Data Producer Heading
atoms.text: # Who are Data Producers?

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L3 02 Who Is A Data Producer-
Who is Data Producer?
atoms.text:
**Data Producer**: A system, service, or user that produces data relevant to a business.

A data consumer can be a data producer. Consider a relational database storing online transactions. It will be a valuable source of shopping trends and patterns for the marketing team.

question.prompt: Choose the correct answer: Which of the following is true for data producers?

answers.text: Only systems can be data producers
Websites can be data producers
Soil moisture sensor can be a data producer
Local SQL DB is not a data producer
Data user can be data producer

atoms.title: Event Data Continued...
atoms.text: # Event and Event Data

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L3 03 What Is Event Data
lots of data
atoms.caption: 2.5 Exabytes of data is produced everyday!

atoms.title: Event and Event Data
atoms.text:
In today's world of connected devices and social media, it is estimated that 2.5 exabytes of data is produced every day, which is equal to 90 years of HD video. 

A considerable portion of this data is event data. Therefore, event data is essential, it will influence how successfully we navigate data product management.

**An Event** is an interaction or an action at a particular moment by a user, a system, or a sensor. 

**Event Data** is generated by such events
Example:
Website - User Interaction 
- Downloads
- Link clicks 
- Form submission

Social Media 
- Shares
- Likes 
- Mention
- Hashtags

Systems 
- Data Replication
- Data Syncing 
- Deletion of jobs

Sensors 
- Motion Detection
- Voice Detection  
- Smoke Detection 
- Temperature Detection

Major Event Data Components:
- Action
- Timestamp
- State 

Additional reading: [How Much Data is produced every day](https://www.northeastern.edu/graduate/blog/how-much-data-produced-every-day/)

answers.text: Data of the events you attend in your life
Data that gets generated by user interaction on website
Data that follows entity modeling rules
Data that is generated by smart devices in homes

question.prompt: Which of the following is not event data?

answers.text: Data generated every time you open a social media app on your phone
Data you query using SQL
Data stored in a DB after an online transaction is completed
Data generated when you click for next set of results on Google

question.prompt: Which of the following is part of an event data?

answers.text: Type of interaction the user had with the app - opened it, closed it, downloaded something, searched something
When exactly did the user do all of this?
Why exactly did the user do it?
What device was the user using?

atoms.title: Event Data Modeling Heading
atoms.text: # Event Data Modeling

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L3 04 Event Data Modeling
Event Data Best Practices
atoms.text:
**Event data modeling** is logically aggregating event data to answer business questions. 

### Event Data Best Practices 
1. Know your current needs
2. Do not track everything
3. Plan for future as well

### Event Data Producers
- Devices
- Web
- Sensors
- Systems
- Social Media

**KPIs and Event Data**: “A performance indicator or key performance indicator (KPI) is a type of performance measurement.KPIs evaluate the success of an organization or of a particular activity in which it engages.”

[Performance Indicator]( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Performance_indicator)

### Ways to measure KPIs
#### Number of users actively using your website or App. Generally measured as :
- Daily Active Users (DAU)
- Weekly Active Users (WAU)
- Monthly Active Users (MAU)
- Primary Measure of User Growth

#### Session Length
- Time spent by a user using your app in one session
- The measure of User Engagement

#### Click-Through Rate
- The ratio of users who clicked an ad or banner versus total users who viewed the page with that ad or banner
- Measures Users Interest in Content or Content Relevance

#### Bounce Rate
- Percentage of users leaving the website after viewing only one page
- Measures effectiveness of entry page

#### Conversion Rate
- Most important KPI
- Percentage of users completing the desired action.
- Desired actions
    - Buying an Item
    - Completing Registration 
    - Downloading  File
- Measures Interest of User in Offering

atoms.title: Knapsack Events
tasks:
The image above is what the first screen of our App looks like right now. Please use this image to answer the following in your template:
What are the possible event types that the product team needs to track for this screen? Provide at least 4.
Use the tabs related to Knapsack Event Data in the Data Infrastructure Strategy Exercises spreadsheet, which is also available to download in the classroom if you haven't already.
Use the tab, Knapsack Event Data Quiz, to aggregate the raw data from the Knapsack Event Data tab in the provided table. You should update the event names. **Hint**COUNTIF is a great way to do this.
Copy the table with the 6 unique event types and the number of times each event type occurred in the Knapsack Event Data Quiz tab into your template document.
Use the raw data and the table you created to find the **number of active users**. If you cannot determine this, please provide the why.
Use the raw data and the table you created to find the **most popular feature**. If you cannot determine this, please provide the why.
Use the raw data and the table you created to find the **least popular feature**. If you cannot determine this, please provide the why.
Use the raw data and the table you created to find the **number of daily active users**. If you cannot determine this, please provide the why.
Use the raw data and the table you created to find the **average session length**. If you cannot determine this, please provide the why.
atoms.positive_feedback: Great job completing these activities. Head to the next page to see the solutions!
atoms.description: Now it's time to think about event data modeling for Knapsack. Please complete the following tasks. The instructions and image are also available in the template document. You will be using both the document template and the spreadsheet. It is recommended that you copy your data table into your document when you have completed that part of the exercise.

atoms.title: Event Quiz 3 Solution
atoms.text: ## Knapsack Event Quiz Solutions

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L3 05 Solution To Quiz 2,3 And 4
Event quiz 2 solution
atoms.text:
*Remember that everything in this course is subjective and your answers may be different, and that is alright. It's most important that you can justify your answers. Data product management is done on a team, not in isolation.*

1. What could be possible event types that the product team needs to track for this screen?
    - open_app
    - hamburger_click
    - search
    - new_product_click
    - product_of_the_day_click
    - close_app


2. Create an event model for the above problem using the provided data.

atoms.title: Event quiz 3 solution
atoms.text:
3. Using the event data model created can you answer the following:
    - Active Users: 125
    - Most Popular Feature: Search
        - 47 Clicks
    - Least Popular Feature: Product of the Day
        - 4 Clicks


4. Daily Active Users - insufficient data, but can be extrapolated 
    - 125 Active Users in 1 hour
    - 24 Hours in a day
    - **125** * **24** = ~ **3000** Daily Active Users
5. Session Length - incomplete data, cannot be extrapolated
    - Timestamps Required

atoms.title: Other Type of Data Producers Heading
atoms.text: # Other Type of Data Producers

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L3 06 Other Type Of Data Producers
OLTP and OLAP
atoms.text:
**OLTP (Online Transaction Processing)**: Information systems that facilitate and manage transaction-oriented applications.
[OLTP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Online_transaction_processing)

**ACID** ([atomicity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atomicity_%28database_systems%29), [consistency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consistency_%28database_systems%29),  [isolation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isolation_%28database_systems%29),  [durability](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Durability_%28database_systems%29) is a set of properties of [database transactions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database_transaction)) intended to guarantee validity even in the event of errors, power failures, etc.
[ACID](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ACID)

OLTP Databases are:
- Inserting, Updating and/or Deleting
- ACID (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation and Durability)
- Relational and Normalized

**OLAP (Online Analytical Processing)**:  tools enable users to analyze multidimensional data interactively from multiple perspectives. OLAP consists of three basic analytical operations: consolidation (roll-up), drill-down, and slicing and dicing.
[OLAP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Online_analytical_processing)

**OLAP Data Warehouses**:
- Combine data from different sources
- For Complex queries
- BI, Reporting and Data Mining
- Not strictly relational or Normalized

question.prompt: Choose correct answer(s) in regard to OLTP

answers.text: OLTP systems are for transactions
OLTP systems have to have normalized data
OLTP systems are strictly relational
OLTP systems have to have atomicity

question.prompt: Which of the following is true about OLAP?

answers.text: OLAP systems are ACID compliant
OLAP systems are not strictly relational
OLAP systems have duplicate data
OLAP and OLTP are similar

atoms.title: ERP Heading
atoms.text: # ERP and CRMs

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L3 07 ERP Systems
ERP and CRM
atoms.text:
**Enterprise resource planning (ERP)** is the integrated management of main business processes, often in real-time and mediated by software and technology.
[ERP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enterprise_resource_planning)

ERP Data Stores
- Common Databases
- **DBMS**: Database Management System
- Share data across departments
- Information flows between business functions
- Relational

**Customer relationship management (CRM)** is an approach to manage a company's interaction with current and potential [customers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Customer). It uses [data analysis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_analysis) about customers' history with a company to improve business relationships with customers, specifically focusing on [customer retention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Customer_retention) and ultimately driving [sales](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sales) growth.
[CRM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Customer_relationship_management)

CRM Data Stores
- Common Databases
- DBMS : Database Management System
- Share data across departments
- Information flows between business functions
- Relational

question.prompt: Which of the following are correct about CRM and ERP?

answers.text: CRM is a type of ERP
ERP is a type of CRM
ERP and CRM have nothing in common
ERP databases are managed by database management system

atoms.title: OLTP heading
atoms.text: # Other Data Producers

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L3 08 Data Through APIs
Other Data Producers
atoms.text:
## Other Data sources to think about:
- Data through APIs
- Data through flat files

### Relational databases built on:

- IBM DB2 
-  Postgres
- Oracle
- MySQL
- Microsoft SQL Server
- Teradata
- Amazon Redshift

### Distributed File Systems such as:
- MapR-FS
- Azure Data Lake Store
- Amazon S3
- HDFS
- NAS

### NoSql and Hadoop systems:
- HBase
- Elasticsearch
- Hive
- MongoDB
- Amazon Elasticsearch Service

atoms.title: headline
atoms.text: # Solution Data Producers

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L3 09 Solution To Quiz 4
Data Structures Intro
atoms.text: # Data Structures

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L3 10 Looking At Data In A New Way
Structured Data
atoms.text:
## Raw Data
"**[Raw data](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raw_data)**, also known as primary data, is data (e.g., numbers, instrument readings, figures, etc.) collected from a source. In the context of examinations, the raw data might be described as a raw score."

## Structured Data
**Structured data** is quantitative data, these are facts and numbers that can be collected, exported, stored, and organized to run analysis on.
- Quantitative Data
- Model Designed by DB Engineers
- Entity Data stored in Rows and Columns
- Relational
- SQL
- OLTP Data

atoms.title: Semi-Structured Data
atoms.text:
## Semi-Structured Data
**Semi-structured data** does not conform to relational databases such as Excel or SQL, but has some level of organization like tags.
- Not strictly Relational
- With Processing it can be stored in a  Relational DB
- NoSQL DB
- CSV, XML and JSON
- Flat Files and API Data

atoms.title: Unstructured Data
atoms.text:
## Unstructured Data
**Unstructured data** is qualitative data. Example: Customer reviews. What customers are saying is important but there is no easy way to run analytics on these comments. 
- Qualitative
- No Model
- Not Relational
- Data Lakes or NoSQL 
- Audio, Video or PDFs
- User Reviews

answers.text: Unstructured Data
Semi-structured Data
Structured Data
Unstructured Data
Semi-structured Data
Structured Data

atoms.description:
_Please complete this activity in the provided templates._

Imagine that you are working as a data product manager for an exercise subscription company that is thinking about releasing new treadmills in addition to standalone exercise courses they already offer. Thus far, this company has only sold regular treadmills.

For this exercise, you will be working on the treadmill team that is developing its next generation of treadmills with advanced voice control features. If you are unfamiliar with exercise companies, you should explore the web a bit to learn more about different exercise companies to get an understanding of how they might be set up.

What types of data producers might a company like this have? Identify

atoms.title: Exercise Company Part 2
tasks: Which are the top two commands that should go in the first release and why?
Among resistance and incline command which one is doing better and why?
Could there be a reason why the number of successful events is lower for certain commands?
Which command among the three having high failure rates should the engineering team be working on? Why?
Any other observations?
atoms.positive_feedback: Great! Thanks for completing that. Head to the next page to see how you did!
atoms.description:
_Please complete this activity in the provided templates._

The data for this exercise can be found in the **Data Infrastructure Strategy Exercises** spreadsheet in tab **Treadmill Exercise Data**.

This exercise company has recently launched an elliptical machine with a new dashboard. This new dashboard is voice-controlled and has been in beta testing to determine which features should be available at launch. For your analysis and insights, a data analyst has created the event data model found in the spreadsheet. You can do further analysis of this data if you would like, but the data provided should be all you would need to answer the following:

atoms.text: # Data Producers Recap

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L3 14 Data Producers Recap
Data Producers Recap Heading
atoms.text:
Wow! You're now 3 quarters, 75%, or most of the way through this course! Great job!

In this lesson, we learned about Data producers, explored event data, and we did some event data modeling, identified different types of data producers. Finally, we touched upon the concepts of Structured, semi-structured, and unstructured data.

Are you ready to tackle the last hurdle...I am so excited for you...see you soon.

atoms.title: Key Terms
atoms.text:
## Key Terms

**Event** is an interaction or an action at a particular moment by a user, a system or a sensor. 

**Event Data** is data generated by events is called event data. Event data primarily comprises action, timestamp and state. 

**KPI** or Key Performance Indicator is a performance measurement for an activity or product.

**Active Users** is the number of users actively using an app or website.

**Session Length** is the amount of time a user spends on the app or website in one session.

**Click Through Rate** is the percentage of users who clicked on an ad or banner.

**Bounce Rate** is the percentage of users leaving a website after viewing only one page is called bounce rate.

**Conversion Rate** is the percentage of users completing a desired action.

**ERP** is usually referred to as a category of business management software — typically a suite of integrated applications — that an organization can use to collect, store, manage and interpret data from many business activities.

**CRM**: Customer relationship management (CRM) is an approach to manage a company's interaction with current and potential customers. It uses data analysis about customers' history with a company to improve business relationships with customers, specifically focusing on customer retention and ultimately driving sales growth.

**Database**: A database is a collection of related data that represents some aspect of the real world. A database system is designed to be built and populated with data for a certain task.

**DBMS**: Database Management System (also known as DBMS) is a software for storing and retrieving users' data by considering appropriate security measures. It allows users to create their own databases as per their requirement.

**Data Warehouse**: Data warehouses are a type of DB, which is often used to store very large amounts of data.

**API**: An application program interface (API) is a set of routines, protocols, and tools for building software applications. Basically, an API specifies how software components should interact.

**Flat File**: A flat file contains records that have no structured interrelationships. A flat file typically consists of a text file, from which all [word processing](https://searchwindowsserver.techtarget.com/definition/word-processor) or other structure characters or [markup](https://whatis.techtarget.com/definition/markup) has been removed.
